references.B74BAN01NAUS: Banfield, A.W.F. 1974. The mammals of Canada. University of Toronto Press, Toronto.
references.B81SCH01NAUS: Schwartz, Charles W., and Elizabeth R. Schwartz. 1981. The Wild mammals of Missouri (2nd Ed.). Univ. of Missouri Press and Missouri Conserv. Dept., Columbia, MO. 356 p.
references.B86JON01NAUS: Jones, J. K., Jr., D. C. Carter, H. H. Genoways, R. S. Hoffman, D. W. Rice, and C. Jones. 1986. Revised checklistof North American mammals north of Mexico, 1986. Occas. Papers Mus., Texas Tech Univ., 107:1-22.
references.B40BUR01SEGP: Burt, W.H., 1940. Territorial behavior and populations of some small mammals in southern Michigan.  Misc. Publications of the  Museum of Zoolgy, Univ. of Michigan. Number 45: 1-58.
references.R99WIL02SEGP: Wilson, D.E. and S. Ruff. 1999. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Washington, DC, Smithsonian Inst. Press. 750 p.
references.B83BAK01NAUS: Baker, Rollin H. 1983. Michigan mammals. Michigan State University Press. 642 pp.
references.B98WHI01NCGP: Whitaker, J.O. Jr. and W.J. Hamilton, Jr. 1998.  Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 583 pp.
references.A28JAC01NAUS: Jackson, H.H. 1928. A taxonomic review of the North Americanlong tailed shrews (genera Sorex and Microsorex). N. Amer. Fauna. 51:1-238.
references.A89GET01NAUS: Getz, L. L. 1989. A 14-year study of BLARINA BREVICAUDA in east-central Illinois. J. Mamm. 70:58-66.
references.A53PRU01NAUS: Pruitt, W.O.,Jr. 1953. An analysis of some physical factors affecting local distribution of short-tailed shrew (Blarina brevicauda) in the northern part of the Lower Pennisnula of MI. U. MI., Mus. Zool., Misc. Pub. No. 79, 39 pp.
references.A86GEO01NAUS: George, S. B., J. R. Choate, and H. H. Genoways. 1986. Blarina bravicauda. Mammalian Species 261:1-9.
references.B62GOL01NAUS: Golley, F.B. 1962. Mammals of Georgia: A study of their distribution and functional role in the ecosystem. University of Georgia Press, Athens, GA. 218 pp.
references.B85WEB01NAUS: Webster, W. D., J. F. Parnell and W. C. Biggs Jr. 1985. Mammals of the Carolinas, Virginia, and Maryland. The University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, NC.

references.A81FRE01NAUS: French, T. W. 1981. Notes on the distribution and taxonomy of short-tailed shrews (genus BLARINA) in the southeast. Brimleyana (6):101-110.
references.B77GOD01NAUS: Godin, A.J. 1977. Wild Mammals of New England. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore. 304 pp.

references.A40BLA01NAUS: Blair, W.F. 1940. Notes on home ranges and populations of the short-tailed shrew. Ecology 21:284-88.
references.N82LEE01NAUS: Lee, D. S., L. B. Funderburg Jr., and M. K. Clark. 1982. A distributional survey of North Carolina mammals. Occasional Papers of the North Carolina Biological Survey, No. 1982-10. North Carolina State. Mus. Nat. Hist., Raleigh, North Carolina. 72 pp.
references.A71BLU01NAUS: Blus, L.J. 1971. Reproduction and survival of short-tailed shrews (Blarina brevicauda) in captivity. Lab. Anim. Sci. 21:884-891.

habitat_description: The Northern Short-tailed Shrew (Blarina brevicauda) is found in a variety of habitats from salt marshes to high mountain forests (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998), especially those with a thick layer of leaf litter and humus or a dense mat of herbaceous roots (Webster et al. 1985). They can also be found in bogs, marshes, near backwaters and inlets, hydric hammocks, flatwoods, and salt marshes (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998).  Other potential habitats for these shrews include brushy areas, woodlands, grasslands, old fields, fencerows, dry uplands, and thickets, provided they are sufficiently moist.  This shrew is typically found where soil moisture is capable of maintaining humidity in the shrew's burrow at a consistently high level (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998). Consequently, this shrew is more restricted to moister wooded habitats in the southern portions of its range.  In New England, occurs in nearly all habitats.  Frequents wooded areas, along the banks of small streams (Godin 1977).  They dig tunnels or use existing ones and construct elaborate underground nest.  The normal home range of this species probably is about 50 yards in diameter and covers about 0.4 acres (Burt 1940).  They mainly breed in early February-March through September with peaks occurring in spring and late summer or early fall.  Gestation is three weeks. Litter size is 3-10 (average 4-6) with three or more litters per year.  They reach sexual maturity in 1-2 months.  Stacy Smith, 12June05 & N. Tarr, 09July14.
